body_html:
This problem had bitten my butt badly at least twice in the past.
The worst part is that session.run(ops) does evaluate ops in order they are provided on cpu version tensorflow, but not gpu version of tensorflow.
@yaroslavvb - A warning to user about undefined order in documentation would only be fair. If at some point order will become defined, then documentation can be updated. Until then you will have people scratching their heads whenever they test code along the lines of

_, actual_weights = session.run([train_op, weights_op])
assert expected_weights == actual_weights

that works as expected with cpu-basedtensorflow, but fails with gpu-based tensorflow.

@yaroslavvb - A warning to user about undefined order in documentation would only be fair. If at some point order will become defined, then documentation can be updated. Until then you will have people scratching their heads whenever they test code along the lines of

body:
This problem had bitten my butt badly at least twice in the past. 
The worst part is that `session.run(ops)` does evaluate `ops` in order they are provided on cpu version tensorflow, but not gpu version of tensorflow.
@yaroslavvb - A warning to user about undefined order in documentation would only be fair. If at some point order will become defined, then documentation can be updated. Until then you will have people scratching their heads whenever they test code along the lines of
```python
_, actual_weights = session.run([train_op, weights_op])
assert expected_weights == actual_weights
```
that works as expected with cpu-basedtensorflow, but fails with gpu-based tensorflow.
